Issues.Title: [Tracking] Consider renaming "easy" label to "good first issue" and using only "help wanted" instead of "up for grabs"
Issues.Body:
Using the **help wanted** label is especially recognized by GitHub and we're trying to get a consistent experience for newcomers. See context at https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/71496
Your repo has the two: **help wanted** and **up for grabs**. Consider converting all the **up for grabs** issues into **help wanted**. Some people added up for grabs in the label description in other repos in case folks are looking for that label instead.

You should also consider adding the project to https://up-for-grabs.net/
See an example PR at https://github.com/up-for-grabs/up-for-grabs.net/pull/3329

/cc @danmoseley
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Tracking] Consider renaming "easy" label to "good first issue" and using only "help wanted" instead of "up for grabs"" (#6937)

Issues.Title: Fake KeyUp events generated when clicing on a WPF application which is running on a remote machine
Issues.Body:
* .NET 6.0
* RDP Server Windows version: Windows Server 2022 21H2 20348.887
* RDP Client Windows version Windows 10 21H2 19044.1889
* Does the bug reproduce also in WPF for .NET Framework 4.8?: Yes

 **Problem description:**
Fake KeyUp events generated when clicing on a WPF application which is running on a remote machine
 
 **Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->
KeyUp event hanler called
 
 **Expected behavior:**
KeyUp event handler should not be called
 
 **Minimal repro:**
- create new WPF app
- Add a KeyUp event handler to the MainWindow and add a TextBlock:

```
<Window x:Class="WpfApp1.MainWindow"
        xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml/presentation"
        xmlns:x="http://schemas.microsoft.com/winfx/2006/xaml"
        xmlns:d="http://schemas.microsoft.com/expression/blend/2008"
        xmlns:mc="http://schemas.openxmlformats.org/markup-compatibility/2006"
        xmlns:local="clr-namespace:WpfApp1"
        mc:Ignorable="d"
        Title="MainWindow" Height="450" Width="800"
        KeyUp="UIElement_OnKeyUp">
    <Grid>
        <TextBlock x:Name="TextBlock" TextWrapping="Wrap" />
    </Grid>
</Window>

```

- Add the event handler to the code:
        private void UIElement_OnKeyUp(object sender, KeyEventArgs e)
        {
            TextBlock.Text += " " + e.Key + "/" + e.SystemKey;
        }

- Run this application on a remote computer and connect to that computer with RDP.
- Deactivate the RDP window
- Activate the RDP window and click on the WPF application

Result:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3104253/186009552-7b53dc84-623f-4c54-b342-6de3b355195b.png)

I'm not pressing any key on the keyboard.

I'm using mstsc to connect to the remote computer. If I'm using a 3rd partry software (mRemoteNG - RDP version = Rdc6) a simialr issue happens, but instead of 3 lines of pressed key, it shows 15 lines... so much more fake keys.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Fake KeyUp events generated when clicing on a WPF application which is running on a remote machine" (#6927)
